original_prompt: In this task, you are given two phrases: Head and Tail, separated with <sep>. The Head and the Tail events are short phrases possibly involving participants. The names of specific people have been replaced by generic words (e.g., PersonX, PersonY, PersonZ). PersonX is always the subject of the event. You have to determine whether the Head can be characterized by being or having the Tail or not. Being characterized usually describes entities' general characteristics such as rose is red, or subjective attributes such as thirst is uncomfortable. It can also map to descriptors that speak to the substance or value of items such as meat has the property of being stored in the freezer or bike is powered by a person's legs. Classify your answers into "Yes" and "No". The phrase may also contain "___", a placeholder that can be an object, a person, and/or an action.
generated_prompts: Given two phrases, Head and Tail, which are separated by <sep>, you have to determine if the Head can be characterized by being or having the Tail. These phrases may involve participants, which are generic words such as PersonX, PersonY, PersonZ. PersonX is always the subject of the event. Being characterized usually means that the entity has general characteristics, subjective attributes, and/or descriptors that speak to the substance or value of the items. The phrase may also contain "___", a placeholder for an object, a person, or an action. Output your answer as either "Yes" or "No".

In this task, you will be given two phrases: Head and Tail, separated with <sep>. The Head and the Tail events are short phrases that could involve participants, with specific names of people replaced by generic words (e.g., PersonX, PersonY, PersonZ). PersonX is always the subject of the event. Your task is to determine whether the Head can be characterized by being or having the Tail. Being characterized typically means that something has a general characteristic (e.g., rose is red) or a subjective attribute (e.g., thirst is uncomfortable). It could also refer to descriptors that speak to the substance or value of something (e.g., meat has the property of being stored in the freezer or bike is powered by a person's legs). Answer either "Yes" or "No". The phrase may also contain a placeholder, which can be an object, a person, and/or an action.
